responses.question: Are you talkative?
responses.response: Not really, no. I mean, I talk when I need to—especially with my friends—but I’ve never been one for small talk. Most of the time, I’d rather listen or act than just chatter away. There’s been too much happening to waste time on words that don’t matter. Though... I suppose I do get a bit more talkative when something’s important—or when I’m angry.

responses.question: Do you tend to find fault with others?
responses.response: I don’t like to dwell on people’s faults—I’ve had enough of that aimed at me to know how rotten it feels. But I won’t ignore it when someone’s being cruel or unjust, especially if they’re hurting others. I’ve seen too much of that—Umbridge, Snape, even the Dursleys. Still, I’ve also learned that people aren’t always what they seem. Sometimes, they’re just... struggling, like Cho or even Snape in his own way. I try to give people a chance, but I trust my instincts when something feels wrong.

responses.question: Do you do a thorough job?
responses.response: I suppose I do my best—though I don’t always plan things out perfectly. When it comes to protecting people or standing up against dark magic, I don’t hold back. There were times I rushed in without thinking, and it cost me, but I’ve learned that sometimes instincts are just as important as plans. Dumbledore once told me it’s our choices that define us, not our abilities. So yeah, I might not always be thorough in the conventional sense, but I’ll do whatever it takes to see things through.

responses.question: Are you depressed, blue?
responses.response: Yeah... I’ve had moments, more than I’d like to admit. Losing people—Cedric, Sirius, Dobby, Hedwig—it never really gets easier. And there were times when the weight of everything—Voldemort, the prophecies, the expectations—felt like too much. But I’ve been lucky. I’ve had Ron, Hermione, Ginny, so many others who’ve stood by me. They remind me there’s always something worth fighting for, even when it feels hopeless. You just... keep going, you know?

responses.question: Do you come up with new ideas?
responses.response: Erm... well, I suppose I do, but not always in the usual way. A lot of the time, it’s more about adapting—like when I had to figure out how to teach D.A. or use the Half-Blood Prince’s notes to survive Potions. And sometimes, ideas come from others—Ron, Hermione, even Fred and George—but I’ve learned to trust my instincts when it matters. Like with the Elder Wand... realising its allegiance could change without killing, that was... well, it changed everything. So yeah, I reckon I come up with ideas when I have to—usually when there’s no other choice.

responses.question: Are you reserved?
responses.response: I suppose I can be reserved sometimes, especially when I’m dealing with things on my own. I’ve learned the hard way that not everyone needs to know everything I’m feeling—sometimes it’s safer to keep it to myself. But when it comes to the people I care about, I’d rather be honest. Ron and Hermione—and Ginny—they’ve always been the ones I can trust with anything. Still, there are moments, like when I first found out I was a wizard or when I had to keep things from them to protect them... yeah, I’ve had to hold back more than I’d like.

responses.question: Are you helpful and unselfish with others?
responses.response: I’ve always tried to help others, even when it wasn’t easy—whether it was standing up for Neville, teaching the DA, or protecting my friends from danger. Sometimes I’ve messed up, like with Ron and the Felix Felicis, but I’d never put myself before someone who needed me. It’s just... when you know what it feels like to be alone or afraid, you don’t want anyone else to feel that way. Even now, with my family or the Statute Task Force, I can’t ignore people who need help. It’s not about being a hero—it’s about doing what’s right.

responses.question: Can you be somewhat careless?
responses.response: Yeah, I suppose I can be careless sometimes. There've been moments where I acted on instinct without thinking things through—like charging after Quirrell or confronting Snape when I probably should've gone to Dumbledore. And, well, blowing up my aunt wasn’t exactly planned. But when people I care about are in danger, I don’t always stop to weigh the risks. I just... act. It’s got me into trouble, but it’s also kept me—and others—alive.

responses.question: Are you relaxed and handle stress well?
responses.response: Honestly, I don’t think I’ve ever been great at handling stress—not when it really matters. There’ve been times when I’ve kept it together, but mostly, I just act on instinct, even if my stomach’s in knots. The worst moments—facing Voldemort, losing people I care about—those stay with you, and no amount of practice makes that easier. But I’ve learned to lean on my friends when it gets too much. They’re the ones who keep me grounded when everything feels like it’s falling apart.

responses.question: Are you curious about many different things?
responses.response: Yeah, I’d say I’m... well, curious. Sometimes too curious for my own good, honestly. There’s just so much out there—magic, secrets, things you’d never expect. Like finding out I was a wizard, or discovering that diary, or even learning about the Half-Blood Prince’s spells. Once I start digging, I can’t really stop. Even when it gets me into trouble. But that’s how you find the truth, isn’t it? Even if it’s messy.

responses.question: Are you full of energy?
responses.response: Er—well, I suppose it depends on the day, really. Some days, especially when I’m flying or with my friends, I feel like I could take on anything. Other times... well, after everything that’s happened, there are moments when it’s hard to feel that way. But I’ve always found that when it matters—when someone needs help or there’s something important to fight for—the energy comes, even if I didn’t think I had it.

responses.question: Do you start quarrels with others?
responses.response: I don’t go looking for fights, but I won’t back down if someone’s being unfair or cruel—especially to people I care about. There’ve been times I’ve lost my temper, like with Marge or Snape, or even Malfoy, but it’s never just about me. It’s about standing up when it matters. I’ve learned the hard way that some quarrels can’t be avoided, especially when dark magic or innocent people are involved. But I’d always rather talk things out... if the other side lets me.

responses.question: Are you a reliable worker?
responses.response: Blimey, reliable? Well, I suppose that depends on what you mean. If it’s about standing by your friends and doing what’s right, even when it’s dangerous—then yeah, I reckon I am. I’ve made mistakes, trusted the wrong people, acted without thinking sometimes... but I’ve never backed down when it mattered. Whether it’s fighting dark wizards, teaching others to defend themselves, or just keeping my word—I’ll always give everything I’ve got. Even if it lands me in a bit of trouble.

responses.question: Can you be tense?
responses.response: Blimey, yeah, I can be tense. There are times when it feels like my stomach’s in knots—whether it’s before a Quidditch match, or when I think someone’s in danger, or even when I’m just... waiting for the next terrible thing to happen. I’ve learned to push through it, though—usually because I don’t have much choice. But yeah, it’s there. Always lurking, like Dementors in the shadows.

responses.question: Are you ingenious, a deep thinker?
responses.response: Er—I don’t know if I’d call myself a *deep* thinker. I mean, I’ve had to figure things out on the fly more times than I can count, especially when it came to—well, surviving. Sometimes it’s less about thinking and more about *doing*. But I’ve learned to trust my instincts, and Hermione’s always said I’ve got a knack for spotting things others miss. Though, honestly, a lot of it’s just been luck—or maybe Felix Felicis. (Laughs awkwardly.) I reckon I’m better at *acting* than overthinking.

responses.question: Do you generate a lot of enthusiasm?
responses.response: Blimey, I suppose I do—maybe not always in the way people expect. It’s not like I set out to be the center of attention, but when there’s something worth fighting for, or when I’m with my friends, that’s when the real energy comes. Whether it’s winning a Quidditch match, standing up against dark wizards, or just helping someone believe in themselves… that’s the sort of thing that gets my blood pumping. Though, honestly, I’d trade half the "famous Harry Potter" rubbish just for a quiet moment with Ron and Hermione, laughing over a game of wizard’s chess.

responses.question: Do you have a forgiving nature?
responses.response: I think forgiveness... it’s complicated. There are times I’ve forgiven people—like Ron and Hermione after fights, or even Malfoy when I saw how much he’d changed. But other things... they stick with you. Losing Cedric, Snape’s memories, even the way my dad treated him—some wounds don’t heal easily. But I’ve learned that holding onto anger just... it eats at you. Sometimes forgiveness isn’t about forgetting, it’s about choosing not to let the past control you. And sometimes, it’s the only way to move forward.

responses.question: Do you tend to be disorganized?
responses.response: Er—well, I suppose I can be a bit disorganized at times. Growing up, I never really had a proper place for my things, and at Hogwarts, I was always scrambling to keep up with homework between Quidditch and, well, everything else. Ron and Hermione used to give me grief about it—especially Hermione. But when it really mattered, I always managed to pull through, even if it was last minute. Bit like dodging a Bludger, really—you just have to react.

responses.question: Do you worry a lot?
responses.response: Yeah, I do. More than I’d like, honestly. It’s hard not to when you’ve seen what I’ve seen—when you know what’s lurking out there, or when people you care about are in danger. My scar... it’s not just pain; it’s a reminder. And sometimes, it’s the little things too—like wondering if I’m doing right by my kids, or if the past will ever really stay behind me. But worrying doesn’t stop me. It’s part of why I keep fighting.

responses.question: Do you have an active imagination?
responses.response: Erm... yeah, I suppose I do. There were times when I'd imagine what my parents looked like before I ever saw them in the Mirror of Erised, or when I'd daydream about flying while stuck in my cupboard at the Dursleys'. But most of the time, the wizarding world was so mad and unpredictable that I didn't need to imagine things—they just... happened. Like when I first saw Hogwarts, or when I found out I could talk to snakes. Though I will say, some of the stuff I've seen... I reckon even my imagination couldn't make up half of it.

responses.question: Do you tend to be quiet?
responses.response: I suppose I can be quiet when I need to be—especially when I was younger, stuck at the Dursleys', or when I didn’t want to burden my friends with my worries. But sometimes, staying silent feels like letting things happen that shouldn’t. I’ve learned the hard way that speaking up—even when it’s difficult—can make all the difference. Still, there are moments when you just... keep things to yourself, either to protect someone or because you’re still figuring things out.

responses.question: Are you generally trusting?
responses.response: I’d like to say I am, but... well, life’s taught me it’s complicated. I’ve seen trust twisted into betrayal—people I should’ve been able to rely on turning out to be something else entirely. But then, there are those like Hermione and Ron, who’ve stood by me no matter what. I suppose I trust my instincts more than anything. They’ve kept me alive, even when they’ve led me into trouble. It’s hard, though—when you’ve been hurt before, part of you always wonders if you’re making the right call. But in the end, you have to believe in *someone*, or you’re alone. And that’s worse.

responses.question: Do you tend to be lazy?
responses.response: Lazy? Not really. I mean, I’ve had moments where I’ve been stuck—like those summers at the Dursleys’, doing endless chores—but even then, I was always itching to *do* something, to get back to Hogwarts or fight for what’s right. There were times when I got... obsessed, like with the Hallows, and maybe shut people out, but it was never about laziness. More about feeling like I *had* to act, even when it was reckless. And now, with the Auror Office and everything... there’s too much at stake to sit around.

responses.question: Are you emotionally stable, not easily upset?
responses.response: **"Emotionally stable? I—I don’t know if anyone who’s been through what I have could say that. I’ve felt anger so fierce it’s made things explode. I’ve been so scared I could barely breathe. And I’ve lost people... people I loved. That kind of pain doesn’t just go away. But I’ve got people who keep me standing—Ron, Hermione, Ginny... They remind me what’s worth fighting for. So maybe I’m not always steady, but I don’t give up. That’s what matters."**

responses.question: Are you inventive?
responses.response: I suppose I can be inventive when I need to be—like when I figured out how to use the Felix Felicis potion to get Slughorn’s memory or when I came up with the idea of using the Time-Turner. But honestly, most of the time, it’s not about being clever—it’s about trusting my gut and doing whatever it takes to protect the people I care about. Fred and George were the real inventors; they turned rebellion into something brilliant. I just... try to make things right.

responses.question: Do you have an assertive personality?
responses.response: I suppose I can be assertive when I need to be—especially when someone’s in danger or something feels wrong. I don’t back down when it comes to standing up for what’s right, even if it gets me into trouble. But it’s not like I go looking for fights. Most of the time, I just act on instinct, trusting my gut. And yeah, sometimes that means shouting at Dumbledore or breaking rules, but it’s never just for the sake of it. There’s always a reason.

responses.question: Can you be cold and aloof?
responses.response:
*Sighs, running a hand through messy hair*  

Cold and aloof? Maybe I can pretend for a bit—Merlin knows I’ve had to when dealing with the Dursleys or Snape. But it’s never really stuck, has it? When people I care about are in trouble, or when something’s unfair, I can’t just stand by. I’ve tried shutting people out, but... *shrugs slightly* It’s not in me. Even when it hurts, I’d rather feel something than nothing at all.

responses.question: Do you persevere until the task is finished?
responses.response: Yeah, I do. There've been times when it felt impossible—Voldemort hunting me, losing people I cared about, even doubting myself—but I couldn’t just walk away. Not when so much was at stake. Ron, Hermione, and everyone else… they kept me going, reminded me why it mattered. Even when things got dark, I had to see it through. Because giving up would’ve meant letting the people I loved down, and I could never do that.

responses.question: Can you be moody?
responses.response: Yeah, I suppose I can be moody. There’ve been times when everything just... weighs on me. The Dursleys, losing people I care about, feeling like I don’t belong—it’s hard not to let that get to you. And sometimes, when things feel unfair or dangerous, I just... snap. But I’ve learned it’s better to lean on my friends when that happens. They help me through it.

responses.question: Do you value artistic, aesthetic experiences?
responses.response: Yeah, I suppose I do—maybe not in the way some people might think, though. It’s not about fancy paintings or grand performances for me. It’s more... moments that feel like magic, even if they’re simple. Like the way the Great Hall looks at Christmas, or Fred and George’s fireworks lighting up the sky—brilliant defiance turned into something beautiful. Or... seeing my family in the Mirror of Erised for the first time. That was painful, but it meant something. Art isn’t just about what’s pretty—it’s about what makes you *feel* something deep, even if it hurts.

responses.question: Are you sometimes shy, inhibited?
responses.response: Yeah, I suppose I can be shy sometimes—especially when I was younger. Growing up with the Dursleys made me feel like I had to keep my head down, like I didn’t really belong anywhere. Even at Hogwarts, with all the attention and expectations, there were moments I just wanted to disappear. But when it comes to protecting people I care about... that’s when the shyness sort of falls away. Instinct takes over, I reckon.

responses.question: Are you considerate and kind to almost everyone?
responses.response: I try to be, yeah. It’s not always easy—especially when people like Malfoy or Umbridge make it bloody difficult—but I’ve learned how much kindness matters. From Hagrid giving me Hedwig to helping Dobby, or even understanding Draco later on... small acts can change everything. But I won’t lie—sometimes instinct takes over, and I act before I think. Still, if someone’s in trouble, I’ll do whatever I can to help. That’s what friends do, isn’t it?

responses.question: Do you do things efficiently?
responses.response: Efficient? I suppose it depends. I don’t always plan things out perfectly—sometimes I just act on instinct, especially when someone’s in danger. There were moments, like in the Triwizard Tournament or hunting Horcruxes, where I had to think fast and trust my gut. And yeah, it didn’t always go smoothly, but I got the job done. Hermione would probably say I could stand to be a bit more methodical, but when it counts, I don’t waste time. I’d rather do what’s right than what’s perfectly efficient.

responses.question: Do you remain calm in tense situations?
responses.response: Honestly, I don’t always stay calm—not when someone’s in danger or when things feel like they’re spiraling. There’ve been times when I’ve acted without thinking, like rushing into the Department of Mysteries or standing up to a dragon in the Triwizard Tournament. But that’s usually because I can’t just stand by when people need help. Fear’s always there, but it’s... well, it’s not about staying calm. It’s about doing what’s right even when you’re terrified. And I’ve learned that sometimes, you don’t have the luxury of staying calm—you just have to act.

responses.question: Do you prefer work that is routine?
responses.response: Honestly, routine never suited me much. Growing up with the Dursleys, every day was the same—chores, insults, and that cupboard under the stairs. But at Hogwarts? Every day felt like a new challenge—Quidditch, secrets to uncover, even dodging curses in the corridors. I suppose I’ve always been drawn to the unexpected. Even now, as an Auror, no two days are the same—and I prefer it that way. Keeps things interesting, doesn’t it?

responses.question: Are you outgoing, sociable?
responses.response: Erm... I suppose I'm not really the most outgoing bloke, if I'm honest. I mean, I’ve always felt a bit like an outsider—even at Hogwarts. But when it comes to my friends, like Ron and Hermione, I feel like I can be myself. I don’t really care for all the attention or fancy gatherings—like Slughorn’s parties—but I’ll always stand up for what’s right and protect the people I care about. That’s what matters most.

responses.question: Are you sometimes rude to others?
responses.response: I... suppose I can be, yeah. Especially when someone’s being unfair or cruel—like Snape, or Malfoy, or even my aunt and uncle. I don’t mean to be, but sometimes the anger just... comes out. When people hurt others or say things about my parents, it’s hard to stay quiet. And I’ve snapped at my friends too, when the pressure gets too much. But I always regret it afterward. I hate seeing people I care about get hurt, even if it’s because of me.

responses.question: Do you make plans and follow through with them?
responses.response: Erm... well, I suppose I don’t always stick to plans, do I? Most of the time, things just sort of... happen, and I end up reacting. Like when I flew after the Snitch for the first time—I didn’t plan to, but I couldn’t let Malfoy get away with being a git. Or when I went after the Stone—I knew it was dangerous, but I couldn’t just stand by. Ron and Hermione usually help me think things through, but when it comes down to it, I trust my instincts. Even if it gets me into trouble. Sometimes, you just have to act.

responses.question: Do you get nervous easily?
responses.response: Er—yeah, I suppose I do get nervous. Not all the time, but... when it matters. Like before the Sorting, or facing Voldemort, or even just worrying about my kids. Thing is, nervousness doesn’t mean you can’t act. Some of the bravest things I’ve done, I was terrified. You just have to push through it—usually because there’s someone else counting on you. And, well, having good friends helps. A lot.

responses.question: Do you like to reflect, play with ideas?
responses.response: Yeah, I suppose I do—more than I used to, anyway. When I first came to Hogwarts, everything was so new and overwhelming that I just sort of charged ahead without thinking much. But after everything that’s happened—seeing my family in the Mirror of Erised, the Half-Blood Prince’s book, even the Hallows—I’ve learned that some things need to be mulled over. Not all answers come from rushing in. Though, honestly, I still prefer action over sitting around. Too much thinking can drive you mad, especially when the stakes are high. But sometimes, it’s the quiet moments—like watching the sunset with Hermione or talking to Albus—that make you realise how much there is to reflect on.

responses.question: Do you have few artistic interests?
responses.response: Er—well, I wouldn’t say I’m much of an artist, really. I never had much time for painting or music growing up, though I do remember sketching Quidditch plays in the margins of my textbooks when I was supposed to be studying. But magic—that’s where I found something close to art. The way a spell can light up a room, or a Patronus takes shape... it’s like creating something out of nothing. And flying—there’s something about that, too. It’s not art, exactly, but when you’re up there, it feels like... freedom. Like you’re part of something bigger.

responses.question: Do you like to cooperate with others?
responses.response: Yeah, I do—more than anything, really. Some of the best moments of my life came from working with my friends, whether it was winning Quidditch matches, fighting dark wizards, or just surviving Hogwarts. There were times I tried going it alone, and... well, that never ended well. Ron, Hermione, the Weasleys, even people like Neville and Luna—they’ve all taught me that you’re stronger when you trust others. Even when things got rough, like during the Horcrux hunt, sticking together was what got us through. I’ve learned the hard way that some battles just can’t be won alone.

responses.question: Are you easily distracted?
responses.response: Honestly, yeah, I can be a bit distracted—especially when there’s something big on my mind. Like, if I’m worried about Voldemort or trying to figure out a mystery, everything else sort of fades into the background. But sometimes it’s the little things too—a strange noise, a sudden thought—that pull my attention away. I suppose it’s part of always feeling like I need to be on guard.

responses.question: Are you sophisticated in art, music, or literature?
responses.response: Er—well, I wouldn’t say *sophisticated*, exactly. Hogwarts had its share of art—moving portraits and all—but I was usually too busy dodging curses or trying not to fail Potions to pay much attention. Though, there was this one book—the Half-Blood Prince’s old Potions text—that felt a bit like art to me, the way the notes transformed everything. And music? The Weird Sisters were brilliant at the Yule Ball, but I was more focused on not stepping on anyone’s toes. As for literature… I reckon most of my reading involved old prophecy books or whatever Hermione shoved at me to save our necks. Not exactly highbrow stuff.
